data.title: Strong Japanese Industrial Output And Accelerating Inflation Raise Chances Of December Rate Hike
data.description:
By Min Joo Kang, Senior Economist, South Korea and Japan

Tokyo CPI inflation beat expectations in October

Tokyo CPI inflation increased 2.8% year-on-year in October (vs 2.5% in September, 2.4% market consensus). October is typically the month when companies adjust prices. A 0.6% month-on-month, seasonally adjusted, increase suggests businesses are raising final prices in response to input price hikes. Prices increased for both goods (0.9%) and services (0.4%), with notable gains in labour-intensive sectors like transport, communication, and entertainment.

The Bank of Japan views this as evidence that sustainable wage growth is driving prices higher. Meanwhile, food prices rose, but at a slower pace. Utilities prices jumped as government subsidies ended. We expect core CPI to remain around 2.5% by the end of this year, backed by solid wage growth.

The Takaichi government plans to fight inflation by reducing the gasoline tax and offering temporary discounts on winter power and gas bills. This may lower headline inflation early next year.

Tokyo CPI rose stronger than expected in October

Industrial output rebounded stronger than expected 2.2% MoM sa in September, for the first time in three months

Industrial production decreased by 0.1% quarter-on-quarter in the third quarter, primarily due to reductions in output related to US tariffs. Transportation equipment and iron/steel output declined in September, likely due to the lingering effects of US tariffs. Still, the recent easing of tariff tensions in several countries should support Japan's production rebound in the coming months. Semiconductor equipment sales rose for a second consecutive month, suggesting that strong global chip demand continued. Meanwhile, retail sales rebounded 0.3% MoM in September but missed the market consensus of 0.8%.

Both IP and retail sales fell in Q3, indicating a GDP contraction for 3Q25. However, a rebound in September points to a gradual economic recovery in the current quarter.

The BoJ cited trade uncertainty as the reason for pausing rate hikes yesterday. However, today’s data indicates a possible economic recovery that could support future rate hikes.

Today’s data supports our view that the BoJ is likely to hike rates in December.

Content Disclaimer

This publication has been prepared by ING solely for information purposes irrespective of a particular user's means, financial situation or investment objectives. The information does not constitute investment recommendation, and nor is it investment, legal or tax advice or an offer or solicitation to purchase or sell any financial instrument. Read more

Original Post

data.title: Watsco: Weak Outlook And Expensive Valuation Keeps Me On The Sidelines
data.description:
I have admired Watsco’s (WSO) business for quite a long time, particularly due to its industry positioning (largest player in a fragmented industry), phenomenal leadership, and quite unique incentive structure that promotes entrepreneurialism at the grass-roots management levels.

However, as Warren Buffett says,

A good business is not always a good purchase – although it’s a good place to look for one.

I believe this holds true for WSO as of now, as it has a great business, and it continues to improve this. Take, for example, the consistently increasing margins of WSO for the last many years. This speaks volumes about the quality of WSO’s business and its industry positioning. No doubt things will remain good for WSO for quite some time.

But WSO’s current valuations leave little room for investors to benefit from this great business, especially after considering near-term external industry-related demand headwinds that WSO currently faces, which were evident in WSO's recent quarterly results.

While the recent fall in the stock price of WSO has made it cheaper, I am still not convinced with the valuation that the company commands despite its superior business. On top of this, the near-term headwind also provides a reason to not own this stock at the current point and valuation and to wait for a better entry. Therefore, I am reiterating my previous hold (neutral) rating on the stock.

Weaker topline marred by external headwinds

Earlier this week, WSO reported its third quarter 2025 results, which were quite disappointing. The company missed both top- and bottom-line estimates, reporting revenue of $2.07 billion, missing the estimates by $70 million, while GAAP EPS remained at $3.98, which also missed by a wide margin of $0.31.

WSO has had back to back two disappointing results. The 2Q 2025 results were quite bad, primarily due to an uneven heating pattern where recooling days appeared during the peak heat period (May-June) of the year. While the management also mentioned macroeconomic headwinds from weaker consumer sentiments as another driver of the weak results, this headwind was largely overlooked by many given the large impact of the weather-related headwinds.

In the third quarter too, WSO witnessed macroeconomic headwinds from weaker consumer sentiment. In fact, the severity of this headwind is much more intense now than it was in the second quarter. The University of Michigan Consumer Confidence Index has consistently been trending lower since the start of the year, with a brief uptick prior to the 2Q25 earnings announcement.

The weak consumer confidence is further exacerbated by the repeated price hikes taken by the HVAC OEMs over the last couple of years, with the latest one of mid- to high single digits announced prior to this year. Combining the repeated price hikes and weak consumer sentiment, the consumer has shown a broad trend of trading down to the base models rather than going with a more premium option.

Moreover, the weak residential construction demand has also proved to be a considerable headwind for the company. While the size of new construction's contribution to overall revenue (15-20%) is not as significant as replacement demand, the significant drop in residential demand took a toll on overall revenue growth.

Going forward the outlook for industry demand looks grim; I expect the external environment to remain somewhat challenging with consumer sentiment still depressed. Furthermore, demand from residential construction is also expected to remain weak.

Profitability a bright spot

While the revenue growth was not up to the mark, WSO's continues to report good margins, with gross margins improving ~150 bps YoY to 27.5%. The improvements were primarily due to the carryover price hike benefit from the price increases made by OEM in spring this year, as old inventory purchased before the price hikes was sold during the quarter. Going forward, I believe this benefit should fade away from next quarter.

However, one should take note of the gradual improvement that the company has made in its margins over the last many years. The gross as well as operating profit margins have expanded considerably over the last 4-5 years when inflation and price hikes were intense. This shows WSO’s pricing power against a highly fragmented consumer base and cost efficiency against smaller peers (WSO is the largest HVAC distributor in a highly fragmented industry).

Going forward, in the near term I do not expect any meaningful change in gross margins. For the medium to long term, WSO is set to continue its last 4-5 years' trend of gradual gross margin improvement. WSO’s management has set an ambitious target of achieving a gross margin of over 30% from the current floor gross margin of 27% under the “Dream Plan 2”.

The 30% gross margin seems quite achievable, as some of WSO’s units already operate at gross margins above 30%, so replicating that across the business should be possible. Furthermore, technology such as Pricefx as well as a higher share of non-equipment segment (30-40% gross margin), should also benefit the margins going forward. Pricefx is a proprietary technology developed by WSO to manage dynamic pricing with specified floor and ceiling prices across the company, serving 100K contractors.

As per management, they have been using this technology for the last 2-3 years, and they are “still younger in that journey.” This implies that there is more to come with respect to harnessing the benefit of dynamic pricing.

Better Cash flow to aid growth

The transition from 410A products to A2L products had been quite a stress on WSO’s balance sheet, as the company had to stock both older 410A products as well as A2L products at the same time. This led much of the capital to tie up with the increased inventory investment. Now, as the transition has been largely complete, the inventory turnover has started to improve from the 3Q 2025.

Source: Author, Seeking Alpha

This has freed up the excess cash tied up with the inventory, which has made WSO’s balance sheet even healthier. Now, given management's stance of favoring inorganic expansion over share repurchases, I believe one could assume a few M&As going forward.

While I usually like share repurchases over any M&As, in the case of WSO, I believe M&A is a better choice for better shareholder returns. First, I believe WSO is currently overvalued, and share repurchases done at expensive valuations often lead to value destruction rather than creation. And second, WSO works in a highly fragmented HVAC distribution industry; being the largest player, WSO enjoys an economy of scale like no other competitor enjoys. This makes WSO a good platform company for bolt-on acquisitions of smaller competitors, which not only increase WSO’s scale and pricing power but also make the newly acquired company more efficient, benefiting WSO in the form of synergies.

Valuation and conclusion

I last rated WSO a hold, particularly due to its expensive valuations, and since then the stock has corrected considerably. However, even now the stock is trading at ~27.8x forward non-GAAP PE ratio, which seems to be quite expensive when compared to the historical range.

Even when compared to peers, WSO appears to be quite expensive. While WSO has a lower non-GAAP forward PE ratio than the peer average, its growth rate is quite lower than the peer average. Even more so, WSO has the lowest growth rate among its peers. While I do believe WSO has superior business fundamentals, the valuation gap, when viewed in conjunction with growth potential, offers little upside from here.

Furthermore, the near-term industry headwinds make me even more skeptical about its near-term potential as an investment. While I would like to rate WSO a buy given its good incentive structure, historical track record, and industry positioning, at the current point in time I would remain on the sidelines and wait for a better opportunity. Until then, I reiterate the hold (neutral) rating on the stock.

data.title: Rates Spark: EUR Curve Wants To Steepen, But Faces Resistance
data.description:
By Michiel Tukker, Senior European Rates Strategist | Padhraic Garvey, CFA, Regional Head of Research, Americas

Higher 10Y euro swap rates through steeper curves

With hard data confirming eurozone growth is on a recovery trajectory, we think 10-year euro swap rates should start considering a push higher. Additionally, inflation came in hotter, bringing the 10-year inflation swap a tick closer to the 2% target again. We acknowledge that the upside potential for euro rates remains limited this year, and we target a 10-year rate of some 10 basis points above the current 2.65%. With growth on track to improve further in 2026, that’s when we aim for the 10Y to look at 3% as the new equilibrium.

For the front end, the wiggle room is much more limited as the ECB’s mantra of being “in a good place” is set on repeat. That means that the 2Y swap rate is firmly anchored between 2.1% and 2.2%. The rise in longer-dated yields must therefore come from steeper curves. That steepening faces resistance from the US, however, where 10Y UST yields dove from 4.5% to 4.0% over the past months. As 10-year US rates stabilise, or even rise as we predict, the 2s10s of the euro curve should feel more comfortable steepening.

Dutch pension reforms too complex to push for steeper 10s30s by itself

Besides US spillovers, we have flattening pressures from the very long end to deal with, whereby the 10s30s steepener seems to have come to a halt. The 10s30s dynamics this year have been almost entirely dictated by the US, but Dutch pension reforms may also play a role. While we still anticipate significant unwinds of 30Y futures and bonds starting in January, we feel the trade may have become too crowded over the summer.

Estimating the timing and size of the flows stemming from the pension reforms is extremely complex, if not impossible, given the available data. Each fund of the 30 scheduled to transition on 1 January 2026 has a unique maturity profile and hedging strategy. Additionally, we remain concerned that IT problems could result in last-minute delays. And now that the US macro landscape is less supportive of 10s30s steepeners, we understand that the trade has become less attractive from a risk-reward perspective.

US Treasuries continue to trade heavily post-FOMC

As the dust settles following Wednesday's Federal Open Market Committee outcome, the new levels for the 2-year and 10-year combo are 3.6% and 4.1%, respectively (both up 10 basis points). The net feeling centers on a Fed Chair that has no problem leaving the funds rate unchanged at the December meeting if that is deemed the thing to do. It comes with residual comfort in the economy. The fact that a 4.3% unemployment rate was specifically referenced as "low" amplifies this point. Instead, there is a degree of discomfort with inflation running at 3% and likely heading higher.

At the same time, there has not been a material change in the ultimate landing level for the funds rate. It's now slightly above 3%, but still within the 3% range. And the 5yr rate continues to trade below the straight line that can be drawn between the 2yr and 10yr rates in a steady fashion. This signals an unwavering expectation that the Fed is, in fact, far from done — it's just a matter of timing. The question now is how robust (or not) the economy manages to be in the next month or so. Yields may continue to push higher—particularly for longer maturities—despite the current pause. However, the lack of hard data remains a challenge due to the ongoing government shutdown. It is an opportunity for the 10yr yield to have a go at testing higher. It might not go too far, but there is a data vacuum that can be filled in, at least until we gain more clarity.

Friday's events and market views

We start with eurozone inflation numbers. The headline French CPI number is expected to come in at just 0.9% year-on-year, a tick below the 1.1% from September. Italian inflation is also expected to nudge lower, from 1.8% YoY to 1.6%. This would then help the eurozone aggregate core CPI down from 2.4% YoY to 2.3%. Due to the US government shutdown, we only expect the Market News International (MNI) Chicago PMI to stand out as notable data.

Content Disclaimer

This publication has been prepared by ING solely for information purposes irrespective of a particular user's means, financial situation or investment objectives. The information does not constitute investment recommendation, and nor is it investment, legal or tax advice or an offer or solicitation to purchase or sell any financial instrument. Read more

Original Post

data.title: FLXR Manages To Remain Competitive In The Income Investing Market
data.description:
A new generation of active bond ETFs with high Sharpe ratios is increasingly replacing the classic (and old) single product isolated in the income investing market. And it’s precisely in this niche that TCW Flexible Income ETF (FLXR) seems to have found room to stand out. Not by chance, the fund was originally launched as a mutual fund (MetWest Flexible Income Fund), like many other active ETFs I’ve analyzed, and later chose to switch its structure to an ETF on June 24, 2024. A choice highly appreciated by the market, as shown by the rapid increase in AUM to $2.06B.

But in practical terms, what sets it apart? In one word: in my opinion, “dynamism.” In a highly segmented market like income investing, actively managed ETFs can shape asset allocation according to their market view, achieving a better Sharpe ratio (higher returns, lower volatility). Need to know more? Here’s a detailed view on FLXR.

What is it?

FLXR is an active multi-sector fixed income ETF, with the primary objective of generating high current income and a secondary one of maintaining long-term capital appreciation. The fund achieves this through active management, with an expense ratio of 0.40%, a 30-day average spread of 0.05%, and a high turnover ratio reported by SA of 181%.

The Bloomberg U.S. Aggregate Bond Index is the point of reference for the management and the index used in the comparison metrics. The fund, however, invests in the 48% of the U.S. bond market (not included in the Bloomberg Agg), that is in areas where the alpha is more accessible (ABS, CMBS, MBS, HY, EM, etc.).

All managed by a team (Bryan Whalen, Jerry Cudzil, Ruben Hovhannisyan) well-known for their expertise in structured credit.

And this is its real distinctive feature. But let me explain it better.

The holding distribution

Selection is not synonymous with low diversification (as often happens); here there are over 1,000 lines in the portfolio and no single position >1% (except for some MBS / Treasury) while maintaining a high-risk profile (AA, mostly guaranteed MBS). About 1/3 of the portfolio is exposed to non-investment grade securities / higher credit risk.

Judging by the holding distribution, the main focus (today), at this moment, remains the short-term, high-quality fixed income part with a strong exposure to agency/high-quality MBS as core. Then it diversifies with Treasury, corporate bond, CLO, other investment grade and non-investment grade tranches which in my opinion makes it very diversified.

So, note well: the backbone of the fund (today) is NOT the classic Treasury, or corporate/HY bond but the agency MBS AA. So first consideration: be careful to consider it a defensive fund, or simply a direct, but more profitable substitute for solutions like SGOV: and even if the alpha doesn’t come from market beta high yield, but from tactical risk allocation, it’s something I like to clarify right away (even if actually quite obvious).

It still has an average duration of 3.2 years, lower than the ~5.8 years of the broad bond benchmark. This makes it less connected to interest rates compared to the classic “Agg”.

Attention to management

Attention, but not in a negative sense. It is necessary to be careful because it is opportunistic, and the asset allocation choices are very clear and shared by the team with operational comments, which are frequently shared (an element that I personally appreciate a lot).

This has made it possible to understand that the alpha generated in the last quarter came more from structured/securitized credit than from plain vanilla corporate.

In fact, FLXR currently has a strong underweight in corporate credit compared to the index. The reason? The management is opportunistic. If I could describe it in one word, after reading TCW’s market comments, I would define it as “counter-cyclical.” In the sense that the opportunistic approach lies in entering the market gradually when the opportunity arises. Seen this way, the underweight in HY and corporate components, and the overweight in short-duration and securitized assets, is justified by the bear steepening process of the yield curve and the expectation of more favorable spreads. But note, not by chance, during the panic sell in April, when spreads widened, TCW increased FLXR’s exposure to HY (even if only as a minor tactical adjustment). And that’s exactly what one looks for in active management.

A personal opinion

This gives FLXR some interesting characteristics from a portfolio integration perspective. First of all, a negative convexity, which matches well with typical core portfolio solutions, and a negative correlation to rates (-0.63). The introduction of FLXR into an IG-oriented portfolio would generate a positive effect in terms of distribution, offering slightly lower volatility than HY.

Likewise, it wouldn’t conflict with HY, since at the moment FLXR is more heavily weighted toward securitized assets.

And when placed on a performance chart, it’s easy to see the contribution that an opportunistic management style like FLXR’s can bring to an income-oriented portfolio in terms of return stabilization during unstable periods such as April 2025.

The peers

Among the peers I have analyzed in the past, I introduce BINC (iShares Flexible Income Active ETF), JPIE (JPMorgan Income ETF), CARY (Angel Oak Income ETF).

The first element that stands out is the overperformance of FLXR, although not excessive. An element that, note well, does not depend on a higher yield. Rather a greater exposure to a segment that has managed to stand out and suffer less from the weight of the steepening: the MBS. And I think this is the biggest difference among this category of ETFs.

This however leads me to also look towards other MBS-centric solutions. And I select two funds that I have analyzed in the past: JMTG and SMBS. The presence of other markets inside FLXR gives it higher yield, while the YTD comparison with SMBS is equal in total return. It will be curious to see if FLXR will be able to maintain alpha, considering that it still has a higher expense ratio than these hybrid or passive solutions.

Risk

I look directly at the MBS, ABS and CMBS segment which today represent on average between 35% and 45% of the portfolio (as well as the main driver of extra yield compared to the Agg).

Curious how these assets are only and exclusively associated with something risky after the 2008 crisis, while here the message that comes through is MBS as a defensive pillar and yield driver. Someone might raise an eyebrow… And it is a topic I have talked about in detail also in other coverages (read here), yet I find myself quite in line also in this case with the management. Of course the risk is clear: in case of systemic shocks, these less liquid assets suddenly widen the spreads, leading to marked differences between NAV and fair value. And personally, I have some concerns regarding the private credit segment (although more directed towards the apparent calm in the CLO market, read here).

But net of this, at least in theory, if a credit shock arrives, not systemic in nature like the 2008 crisis, FLXR could have smaller drawdowns compared to funds more loaded with traditional IG/HY corporate precisely because it uses this event opportunistically, as happened in April 2025 (even if it was not a real shock).

Conclusion

I was pleasantly involved by the analysis of FLXR. From the study of TCW’s view, through the opportunistic strategy, up to the analysis of the holding distribution, this ETF has carried me into a positive narrative. Of course, active management does not mean certainty of returns, and in shock contexts the credit market suffers a bit in all segments, and if you follow me, you will surely know what my recent concerns are regarding the private credit segment. But as of today, compared to the peers, it has at least demonstrated greater resilience. For this reason, net of the risks of the sector, I think that for FLXR the BUY rating is justified.

data.title: Mastercard: This Is Visa's Year (Rating Downgrade)
data.description:
Mastercard (MA) shares are up marginally after reporting results that exceeded expectations for the third quarter.

To me, the main topic of discussion should be the payment volume growth gap from Visa (V) reaching a multi-year low. Even more, in the United States, Visa's volume growth surpassed Mastercard's for the first time in many years.

This is a sign of what's to come in my view, as Mastercard's usual tailwinds for higher growth have reached their potential.

I argue that for the first time since I started covering the two payment empires, we've reached a point that I can no longer justify a "Buy" rating for Mastercard in light of the setup with Visa.

Let's dive in.

Background

I've been covering Mastercard and Visa on Seeking Alpha for a few years now, maintaining a bullish view on both of them all throughout, though I did have a slight preference for Visa.

Going back to my first article in April 2023, trying to decide between the two was really a moot point. Still, I argued that in the long term, I see Visa delivering better results due to several key differences.

So far, things have developed as I thought, but it hasn't been too meaningful to affect results. However, I think that from now on, the case for Visa over Mastercard will become stronger, and the recent quarter is a good example.

The Differences Between Mastercard And Visa Are Set To Take Center Stage

Let's be honest, Mastercard and Visa are nearly identical businesses. Every time one of them comes up with a novel offering, the other immediately finds a way to offer the same thing. Recently, we saw this with agentic commerce and stablecoins.

So, where do they actually differ? First and foremost, size. Visa is about 60% larger than Mastercard based on payment volumes and about 25% larger in terms of revenue.

Second, business mix. Mastercard generates 40% of its revenues from value-added services, while Visa is at 28%.

Third, they have some strategic differences, specifically when it comes to aggressiveness about client incentives. Mastercard is paying out about 10 points more to clients, with its rebate ratio consistently at the high thirties, compared to Visa at the high twenties.

Fourth, margins. Mainly due to the higher client incentives, Visa is about 850 bps more profitable compared to Mastercard.

Lastly, valuation. At current prices, Mastercard trades at 30 times 2026 EPS, while Visa trades at 26 times 2026 EPS.

Mastercard's higher valuation is commonly and rightfully justified by its historically higher growth. But, going forward, I think the differences between the companies are set to lead to a narrowing of this gap.

Historically, as we saw, Mastercard went the route of paying higher incentives, thereby converting customers from Visa and winning over new customers. Also, it was further ahead in value-added services.

Mastercard Is Seeing Visa Breathing Down Its Neck In Q3

Mastercard's results, by themselves, were everything investors learned to expect from the company. Revenues grew 15% on a constant currency basis, reaching $8.6 billion. Operating income rose 18%, with a 50 bps improvement in margins. Net income was up a lower 10% due to a higher tax rate, and EPS was up 13%, benefiting from buybacks.

Below the surface is where things get more interesting. Value-added services, representing about 40% of Mastercard's revenue, were up 22% on a constant currency basis. Although it's impressive, this marks another quarter of slower growth compared to Visa, which is catching up on market share.

This was my expectation all along: since Visa has more existing customers to provide value-added services to, it will eventually surpass Mastercard's market share.

Meanwhile, Visa has also become more aggressive in defending its market share in core payments. And, after Mastercard had several key customer wins last year, as we lap their effect, we see that the gap in volumes is the lowest it has been in a very long time.

The most concerning part, from Mastercard's perspective, is that Visa grew its U.S. volumes faster, at 7.6% compared to Mastercard's 7.0%, for the first time since I've been tracking the two. Reminder, Visa is nearly 2.4x larger in terms of U.S. payment volumes.

Looking ahead to next quarter, Mastercard expects to see growth in the high teens, inclusive of a 5%-6% contribution from FX and acquisitions. Meanwhile, Visa guided for the high end of low-double-digit growth.

If we take their outlooks and translate them into numbers, I think we can assume Mastercard is expecting 17% revenue growth, or 12% organically, while Visa is expecting 13%-14% organic growth.

So, the bottom line is Mastercard continues to deliver extraordinary numbers, but they are no longer more extraordinary than Visa's. In fact, in many areas, they are less extraordinary.

Valuation & Outlook

To me, what we saw in Q3 is going to continue. Currently, consensus sees Mastercard growing revenues by 12% in 2026, while Visa is expected to grow 11%. This would be the narrowest gap in a long time.

Meanwhile, considering their CY26 multiples, Mastercard's premium of 15% is about in line with the historical average, but it's not supported by the same growth gap, as we discussed.

On its own, Mastercard trades at the high end of its historical valuation range, ahead of what's going to be a lower growth period (though still strong at low double digits).

In my mind, considering all of the above, Mastercard trades at a fair valuation.

Conclusion

Mastercard remains one of the best companies I know of, and I believe that investors who hold it for the long term will benefit.

That said, I think that in Q3, we saw the growth lead over Visa at its lowest level, and I estimate the closing of the gap will continue.

This time, it will take center stage and be much more obvious for investors, as it will come down to actual results rather than future estimates.

As such, I can't recommend buying Mastercard here, at a sizeable premium, when Visa is a better prospect in my view. Therefore, I downgrade Mastercard to "Hold."

One important clarification: I wouldn't sell Mastercard shares and replace them with Visa if there are meaningful capital gains involved. I do think Visa is meaningfully more attractive, but not to this extent.

data.title: Politics And The Markets 10/31/25
data.description:
This is the forum for daily political discussion on Seeking Alpha. A new version is published every market day.

Please don't leave political comments on other articles or posts on the site.

The comments below are not regulated with the same rigor as the rest of the site, and this is an 'enter at your own risk' area as discussion can get very heated. If you can't stand the heat... you know what they say...

More on Today's Markets:

Moderation Guidelines:

We remove comments under the following categories:

  • Personal attacks on another user account
  • Anti-Vaxxer or covid related misinformation
  • Stereotyping, prejudiced or racist language about individuals or the topic under discussion.
  • Inciting violence messages, encouraging hate groups and political violence.

Regardless of which side of the political divide you find yourself, please be courteous and don't direct abuse at other users.

For any issue with regards to comments please email us at : moderation@seekingalpha.com.

Seeking Alpha's Disclosure: Past performance is no guarantee of future results. No recommendation or advice is being given as to whether any investment is suitable for a particular investor. Any views or opinions expressed above may not reflect those of Seeking Alpha as a whole. Seeking Alpha is not a licensed securities dealer, broker or US investment adviser or investment bank. Our analysts are third party authors that include both professional investors and individual investors who may not be licensed or certified by any institute or regulatory body.

data.title: CBIZ: How Marcum's Deal Reshapes Its Position In The Mid-Market
data.description:
CBIZ, Inc. (CBZ) is an American company that provides a range of professional services, such as accounting, tax, advisory, benefits, and insurance. It primarily serves middle-market businesses that require integrated, expert services.

Many investors are accustomed to CBIZ's strategy, known as the "string of pearls," which focuses on small, guaranteed-to-win acquisitions. So they view Marcum's deal through the same lens as smaller, recurring CBIZ deals they have seen over the past years. They applied the same risk standards used for smaller acquisitions, overlooking the potential benefits of an agreement of this magnitude, which would establish the company as one of the seven largest in accounting services, thereby making it more attractive to larger clients. I believe the fear surrounding the company is temporary, while its new market position is permanent.

CBIZ can now offer a one-stop shop for everything, creating a powerful customer relationship and higher barriers for competitors. The market is underestimating the potential benefits of the deal not only in terms of cost savings, which are expected to exceed $35 million this year, but also the enormous opportunities of cross-selling of CBIZ legacy services, such as insurance and employee benefits, to Marcum's broad customer base.

Indeed, the new entity has significant debt of $1.6 billion; however, the company has a plan to reduce it, targeting a net leverage ratio of 2.0x - 2.5x by 2027, through the strong expected cash flows. Interestingly, it postponed its debt reduction plan from 2026 to 2027 due to stock buybacks of 800,000 shares during the third quarter, which is a strong indication of the current low stock price.

Overall, Marcum's deal was essential to expanding the company's size and achieving geographic reach, challenging competitors by offering all clients' needs in one place, eliminating the need for them to seek out competitors.

Company Restructure

Indeed, a deal of this size requires substantial financing; therefore, the deal was financed through a new $2 billion credit facility, comprising a $1.4 billion term loan. This step raised the pro-forma net-debt-to-EBITDA ratio to approximately 3.7×, which worried the market. However, a substantial portion (approx. 5%) of the transaction was paid in CBIZ shares, subject to Marcum's management's commitment to work with the new entity for 4 years. This means the partners who built Marcum and its relationships now hold a meaningful equity interest in CBIZ, and their long-term incentives are tied to the merger's success, reducing the departure of talent and clients after the acquisition, which is a crucial detail often overlooked by the market, and significantly reduces the risks of the merger.

Strong Market

CBIZ is built for the middle market, focusing on medium-sized companies. Marcum deal doubles CBIZ's dominance in this stable and profitable market, which is the backbone of growth and employment in the U.S. economy. This segment tends to be more resilient in economic fluctuations. Besides, these types of companies are mostly too big for local small accounting firms, yet too small for large firms such as the Big Four. Thus, they don't receive much attention from either side, opening the way for CBIZ.

In addition, about 72% of company revenues come from recurring services that provide a stable and predictable base, such as tax compliance and payroll services, which are essential regardless of the state of the economy.

Moreover, CBIZ's employee benefits and insurance sectors were always strong and stable, but their main challenge was finding new clients; Marcum's deal opened a vast market of tens of thousands of clients who joined CBIZ.

Financials

CBIZ Inc. achieved strong performance in the third quarter, where revenues increased by 58.1% to $693.8 million, driven by the financial services sector, with revenues increasing by 80% to $579 million, and the Marcum merger. While revenue was slightly softer than expectations ($709 million), the integration with Marcum started to pay off, through improving operational efficiency and reducing costs, which made profits exceed estimates at $1.01 per share.

The adjusted EBITDA reached $120 million (+58.5% YoY). However, the impact of financing the acquisition was clear, as the Net Income declined to $30.1 million due to higher interest expenses of $28 million driven by higher debt levels incurred to fund the cash portion of the acquisition, demonstrating the short-term pressures that fear market.

It seems that CBIZ is keen to transform the Marcum deal into added value for shareholders through stock buybacks and improving margins, despite integration costs.

For the full year, the company reaffirmed its guidance for total revenues of $2.8 billion and $2.95 billion, and adjusted EPS of $3.60 - 3.65, reflecting a significant increase in profitability from the first year as a result of the deal.

A key consideration is the seasonality of accounting and tax work, which peaks in the first and second quarters. CBIZ revenues from the insurance and benefits sector were stable, mitigating the intensity of seasonality. Following the acquisition deal, which doubles the size of the financial services sector, the combined profits are expected to be more seasonal, with a higher concentration in the first half of the year. Therefore, any investor who does not consider this point might worry about the results of the second half quarters, although this is merely a natural rhythm depending on the company's nature.

Valuation

According to the company's guidance, it expects adjusted EBITDA of $450 million for 2025. CBZ has an EV/EBITDA of approximately 13x. However, the average multiple of its closest competitors is 15x. We assume a conservative EV/EBITDA of 12x to put a margin of safety. With that in mind and after subtracting net debt of $1600 million, the equity value comes to $3800 million, or $70 per share (shares outstanding at 54.4 million).

The price target represents a potential increase of more than 30% from the current trading levels $53.

Risks

There are risks associated with the cultural merger between two companies of this enormous size, as any failure to achieve the integration between them could lead to operational disruptions. Additionally, the SEC's penalties against Marcum due to systematic quality control failures introduce a layer of reputational risk for the company, even if they are related to 2023.

Any economic slowdown can impact the company's revenues, particularly given the current level of debt, making it more sensitive to changes in interest rates. Therefore, failure to comply with loan terms could be catastrophic.

The employees of every professional services company are its primary capital; thus, if Marcum's management, who built strong relationships, decided to leave, it could lead to a departure of their clients and significantly erode the deal's value. However, the CEO was asked about this and said they are pleased with both the client and staff retention rates.

According to the CBIZ report on the mid-sized companies market, some clients have begun postponing certain growth plans due to market uncertainty. So any severe economic recession could slow growth and make debt servicing difficult.

Although the deal rationale is sound, it introduces a level of complexity the management has not previously encountered. As a result, they may focus on resolving daily integration issues rather than addressing key business objectives and staying abreast of new developments in AI and other areas.

Conclusion

Marcum's deal introduced CBIZ to a short-term uncertainty, as the market priced in the failure risks but did not consider the success reward. Considering the recent strong performance, low valuation compared to peers, and the company's repurchase of approximately 800,000 shares, which confirms the cheap stock price, it would be fair to give a "Buy" rating. However, investors should monitor debt repayment progress each quarter, as this is an essential event that will significantly reduce risks and lead to higher multiples.

data.title: IUS: Healthy Returns, Risk Metrics, Secure Its Place On ETF Investors' Short List
data.description:
Today, I would like to rediscuss the Invesco RAFI™ Strategic US ETF (IUS), a passively managed exchange-traded fund with the performance I called "inspiring" in April 2022, though I stopped short of the Buy rating as its quality characteristics did not impress me, plus I found its valuation not particularly comfortable (I was more into maximalist value portfolios as the bear market was raging).

So it has been about three and a half years, and I do believe a fresh review is overdue, especially considering that investor attention to IUS has been rather strong, as the AUM has risen approximately 2.75x since April 2022.

But before we delve into the analysis, have I changed my view on IUS? Mostly not. IUS has a place in the cohort of ETFs I am constructive on, but nothing more. This is a Hold rating at best. Sure, as I have already said in the previous article, IUS is a good candidate for a quality investor's ETF shortlist, but it would clearly be an exaggeration to say that it has the potential to outperform the iShares Core S&P 500 ETF (IVV) or the iShares Russell 1000 ETF (IWB) in the current market conditions.

Basics of The Invesco RAFI™ Strategic US ETF

  • Inception: September 12, 2018
  • Investment Adviser: Invesco Capital Management LLC
  • AUM: $689.01 million, as of October 30
  • Expense Ratio: 0.19%
  • 5-Year Annualized Total Return (October 2020–September 2025): 17.45% vs. IVV's 16.45%

IUS Strategy Recap

As explained on the Invesco website, the Invesco Strategic US Index, which "...is designed to measure the performance of high quality, large-sized US companies," is the very core of IUS' passive strategy. The index is reconstituted just once a year.

It has a selection and weighting process that I usually call sophisticated or labyrinthine—smart beta at its best. That is to say, the index provider goes very much beyond just picking the most expensive names in the market and assigning them weights depending on their market caps (this is almost what the S&P 500 does, but of course with a lot of nuances). Instead, it relies on the "business-size score," which is the main instrument in deciding whether a company has quality high enough to qualify for the index. As described by IUS:

The securities are assigned a business-size score based on the equally-weighted average of sales, operating cash flow, total return of capital and book value over the prior five years or life of the security. For real estate securities, operating cash flow is replaced by funds from operations and book value is replaced by total assets. The securities are then assigned a quality score based on the equally-weighted average of efficiency (ratio of sales-to-assets in the prior year) and growth (percentage change in ratio of sales-to-assets over the prior five years or life of the security). Finally, each eligible security is ranked in descending order by its Business-Size score. For inclusion in the index, securities ranked in the top 90% by Business-Size score are eligible and, of those 80% with the highest Quality score. Securities in the Index are weighted based on their float-adjusted Business-Size scores.

IUS Performance: Good At Mitigating Losses, But Bad At Capturing Upside

Incepted in September 2018, IUS has had a quite mixed performance, with grossly successful years followed by rather soft ones. So beating IVV and IWB (I have added the latter ETF as the Russell 1000 Index is IUS' benchmark as per the factsheet, and IVV is a market proxy that I use in my ETF research) was not something its business-size score-centered strategy was potent enough to accomplish.

However, it still should be noted that it has outperformed such quality factor-focused peers as the Fidelity Quality Factor ETF (FQAL), the iShares MSCI USA Quality Factor ETF (QUAL), and the JPMorgan U.S. Quality Factor ETF (JQUA), though the Invesco S&P 500® Quality ETF (SPHQ) was racier.

Annual Performance

Delving deeper, we see that IUS outperformed IWB and IVV only in October–December 2018, 2021, and 2022. Its performance in 2023–9M 2025 was especially bleak.

Period IUS IWB IVV
October–December 2018 -13.40% -13.74% -13.45%
2019 29.34% 31.06% 31.25%
2020 15.14% 20.77% 18.40%
2021 32.18% 26.32% 28.76%
2022 -8.35% -19.19% -18.16%
2023 20.78% 26.41% 26.32%
2024 16.51% 24.32% 24.93%
January–September 2025 12.52% 14.35% 14.75%

Prepared by the author using data from Portfolio Visualizer

So my calculations show the median annual (including shorter periods in 2018 and 2025) active return of -1.78% (with IWB used as a benchmark; with IVV selected as a benchmark, it is even weaker at -2.07%), which clearly does not make me feel strongly bullish on IUS.

On top of that, IUS has significantly underperformed the S&P 500 index since my April 2022 article.

Annualized Returns and Other Considerations

Now let us take a close look at the annualized returns and a few select risk metrics for the October 2018–September 2025 period.

Here, we see the main advantage of IUS over IVV and IWB: it has greater immunity to bearish forces, which is reflected in its downside capture ratio of 94.09% and the fact that in its worst year, it had only a 13.4% loss (it was the last three months of 2018; the 2022 loss was just 8.35%).

Moreover, its maximum drawdown over the period was 22.65% (the one it delivered in March 2020), which of course does not look comfortable at all, but almost all ETFs in the group (JQUA is an exception) still delivered much deeper drawdowns (for most, the deepest drawdowns were in 2022, not 2020).

However, while this clearly speaks in its favor, I do not think this is enough for a Buy thesis as there are other facts to consider.

  • Its annualized return over the period was weaker than those of IVV, IWB, and SPHQ.
  • It was more volatile than SPHQ, JQUA, and FQAL, as illustrated by the standard deviation.
  • Its upside capture ratio was just 94.53% (compared to, for instance, 100.85% of QUAL), which means it is quite weak at benefitting from tech-, growth factor-, and AI enthusiasm-driven bull markets like the one the S&P 500 is currently in.

IUS Portfolio Analysis

As of October 29, there were 544 common stocks, REITs, and ADRs in the IUS portfolio, key among them being Alphabet Inc. (GOOGL), with a 6.09% weight. Importantly, there are only Class A shares in this portfolio, and Class C shares (GOOG) are absent.

A massive 91.6% of IUS' net assets is allocated to S&P 500 constituents. However, as a result of the ETF's focus on the business-size score, most of these names are value or value-ish stocks, as I will explain shortly.

Parameter IUS IVV
Stocks present in both IUS and IVV portfolios 91.76% 94.71%

Calculated by the author using data from the ETFs

Key Ten Holdings

Looking at the cohort of the key ten holdings, we see that IUS has significantly underweighted the locomotives of the bull market like NVIDIA Corporation (NVDA) and Microsoft Corporation (MSFT), while significantly boosting exposure to the old-economy names like Berkshire Hathaway Inc. (BRK.B) and Chevron Corporation (CVX).

Company Weight in IUS Weight in IVV Sector Market Cap, $ Billion
GOOGL 6.09% 4.89% Communication 3,323.91
Apple Inc. (AAPL) 4.85% 6.17% Information Technology 4,002.45
MSFT 3.38% 6.21% Information Technology 4,025.39
Meta Platforms, Inc. (META) 2.62% 2.52% Communication 1,888.30
Amazon.com, Inc. (AMZN) 2.51% 3.45% Consumer Discretionary 2,456.13
Exxon Mobil Corporation (XOM) 2.35% 0.76% Energy 496.46
BRK.B 2.28% 1.35% Financials 1,025.99
NVDA 2.15% 7.80% Information Technology 5,031.07
CVX 1.57% 0.46% Energy 314.74
UnitedHealth Group Incorporated (UNH) 1.47% 0.50% Health Care 321.75

Data from Seeking Alpha and the ETFs. Market cap data as of October 30. For IVV, the weights of GOOG and GOOGL were summed up.

IUS Sector Mix

The direct consequence of the Invesco Strategic US Index's selection and weighting scheme is that IUS has a sector mix notably different from those of IVV and IWB.

  • Compared to IVV, it is underweight in IT, financials, real estate, and utilities. It is overweight in all other seven GICS sectors.
  • Its differences from IWB are similar, though there are minor nuances related to weights.
  • A minor remark I should make here is that IUS' relatively large exposure to energy has been quite a detractor this year and one of the reasons why it is underperforming IVV, as the sector's returns have been rather soft amid volatile and mostly unfavorable oil prices.

IUS Factor Mix

What is the essence of IUS' factor story? Let us discuss the list of metrics below (which is certainly not exhaustive but still comprises the most important parameters) that I calculated using financial data from Seeking Alpha and the ETFs.

Metrics IUS IVV
Market Cap, $ Billion 921.66 1,525
Adjusted EY 4.54% 3.44%
Adjusted P/S 5.45 10.04
Adjusted EV/EBITDA 18.05 23.36
Revenue Fwd 7.65% 14.63%
EPS Fwd 11.86% 20.85%
EBITDA Fwd 9.38% 18.54%
Adjusted ROE 19.59% 20.35%
ROA 11.15% 16.26%
ROTC 14.70% 19.81%
24M Beta 0.90 1.15
60M Beta 1.00 1.16
Quant Valuation B- or higher 19.18% 6.48%
Quant Growth B- or higher 30.21% 45.43%
Quant Profitability B- or higher 94.97% 94.02%
Quant EPS Revisions B- or higher 68.07% 75.40%
Quant Momentum B- or higher 58.50% 69.47%

Calculated by the author. Financial data as of October 30

Let me summarize a few essential takeaways.

  • IUS is a solid choice for value investors who would not compromise on quality. Indeed, a combination of a weighted average adjusted earnings yield of 4.54% and a nearly 95% allocation to companies with a B- Quant Profitability rating or higher makes an impression.
  • Low volatility-focused investors should appreciate the weighted average 24-month beta of its portfolio of 0.9.
  • However, for growth and momentum investors (and the S&P 500 is in the bull market driven by these exact factors), IUS has little to offer (a close to 2x difference in the weighted average forward growth rates of IUS and IVV is telling).

Final Thoughts

All in all, the Invesco RAFI™ Strategic US ETF is certainly a decent investment vehicle with healthy returns secured by its carefully calibrated strategy. Alas, 'healthy returns' and consistent outperformance are not the same. Sure, IUS has proved that it can deliver more comfortable maximum drawdowns than most of its peers, but beating IVV systematically is certainly not what it can do. So, while appreciating its quality characteristics, I maintain the Hold rating.

data.title: Civista Bancshares: Upgrading To Buy After Incorporating The Negative EPS Outlook
data.description:
Since I downgraded Civista Bancshares, Inc. (CIVB) in April 2025, the stock price has declined by around 4%. Also, since then, the company has announced a new public offering of its shares and the acquisition of Farmers Savings Bank. These two transactions are not big, but they will have a material dilution effect on per-share items. To update my earnings estimates and investment thesis, I’m going to start by looking at the company’s balance sheet and earnings potential.

Acquisition, Pipelines to Counter Risks from Tariffs

Loan growth over the last two quarters has been even worse than I’d imagined in my last report on the company, which I wrote in April. The net loan balance at the end of September was 0.3% lower than the balance at the end of March 2025. The management blamed “a bunch of expected payoffs” for the performance in the conference call. Further, the management said that it wasn't aggressive in trying to bring new business into the bank.

There is hope for a recovery, partly because the loan pipelines are strong. The management mentioned in the conference call that the current pipeline is higher than it was last year, and significantly higher than it was earlier in the year.

Moreover, Civista Bancshares is on track to close the acquisition of Farmers Savings Bank in November. Farmers operated in Northeast Ohio and had around $104 million in net loans at the time when the transaction was announced, as per a press release. This acquisition can boost the loan balance by around 3.4% in the last quarter of 2025.

A threat to loan growth is the US trade policy. Civista Bancshares mostly operates in Ohio, whose economy is affected to a significant degree by US-Canada relations. According to the U.S. Trade Representative, around 35% of Ohio’s exports went to Canada in 2024. To put this in perspective, only around 15.8% of the US’s exports go to Canada, according to the Census Bureau.

Unfortunately, the US-Canada relations have taken a turn for the worse in recent weeks. The US President has announced a 10% increase in tariffs on Canadian goods after recent advertisements by Ontario’s Premier showing President Reagan arguing against tariffs, according to news reports. However, the Senate has voted to repeal the tariffs on Canada, according to the latest news reports.

The management mentioned in the conference call that it is targeting mid-single-digit loan growth going forward. Considering the acquisition, the pipelines, and the risks related to tariffs, I’m expecting the loan book to grow by 4.0% in 4Q’25, which will take the full-year loan growth to 4.5%. Further, for 2026, I’m expecting loan growth of 4.1%. In addition, I’m assuming deposits will grow in line with loans.

Acquisition, Rate Cuts to Lift the Margin

After the net interest margin grew by an impressive 28 basis points in the first half of this year, it fell by 6 basis points in the third quarter of the year. This fall wasn’t unexpected, and I’m not worried about it. There is a chance of net interest margin growth in the next couple of quarters, albeit by only a small amount.

The management mentioned in the conference call that the margin could expand by 5 basis points in 4Q’25 due to Fed funds rate cuts and the acquisition of Farmers Savings Bank.

Beyond 4Q’25, I’m expecting further margin expansion because I’m expecting 50 basis points of Fed funds rate cuts in 2026. Civista Bancshares’ deposit cost is quite rate-sensitive, as interest-bearing demand, savings, and money market deposits made up around 48% of total deposits. These deposits can be repriced soon after rate cuts. Hence, the deposit cost will fall as market interest rates decline, leading to margin expansion.

Overall, I’m expecting the net interest margin to rise by 5 basis points in 4Q’25 and then by 6 basis points in 2026.

Expecting the Efficiency Ratio to Worsen

Apart from giving small boosts to the loan balance and net interest margin, the acquisition will also benefit earnings through cost savings. The management mentioned in the conference call that it expected to make cost savings through the system conversion, which will reduce contract expenses. Further, the management is planning staff reduction following the merger.

Civista Bancshares has shown remarkable expense discipline so far this year. The efficiency ratio improved to 64.1% in 3Q’25 from 71.9% in 3Q’24. Tariffs and their impact on inflation can raise the efficiency ratio in the future. However, the Fed Chair did note that, “I think it would not be appropriate to just ignore or assume away the inflation issue; at the same time, I think the risk of higher, more persistent inflation has declined significantly since April,” according to news reports.

Considering the benefits from the acquisition and tariff threats, I’m expecting the efficiency ratio to rise to 66% in 2026 from 64.1% in 3Q’25.

Expecting EPS of $2.6 for 2025 and $2.5 for 2026

At the time I last wrote about Civista Bancshares in April, the company had yet to announce its plans for an acquisition and a new public offering of shares. Under the public offering, Civista Bancshares’ shares outstanding increased by 3,788,238 shares, or 25%, according to details given in the earnings release. As a result, my previous report and the earnings estimate I gave in it are outdated.

I’m now expecting the earnings per share to dip from the level seen in the first nine months of 2025, mostly because of the dilution effect of the new share issuance. The net income (not per share) will likely be higher because of low loan growth and slight margin expansion.

I’m also assuming the non-interest income will remain rangebound after a small acquisition-related jump in 4Q’25. Further, I’m assuming the provision expense to loan ratio will remain near a normal level of 0.03% after spiking in 4Q’25 due to the acquisition.

Overall, I’m expecting Civista Bancshares to report an EPS of $0.56 per share in 4Q’25, which will take full-year earnings to $2.60. For 2026, I’m expecting an EPS of $2.50.

The street consensus estimate is similar to my estimates and can be viewed here.

Upgrading to Buy

I adopted a hold rating on Civista Bancshares in April. Since then, the stock price has dropped by around 4%. As the company has issued new shares and announced an upcoming acquisition since my last report, my previous investment thesis is outdated. To update my valuation, I’m using the historical average price-to-earnings (“P/E”) and price-to-tangible book (“P/TB”) multiples given below.

Multiplying the average P/E multiple by my EPS forecast gives a target price of $20.9 for the end of 2026.

Multiplying the average P/TB multiple by my TBVPS forecast gives a target price of $27.4 for the end of 2026.

The average price target comes out to $24.1, which suggests an 11.5% price upside from the October 29 closing market price. Civista Bancshares also offers a dividend yield of 3.1% at a quarterly dividend rate of $0.17 per share. Adding the price upside to the dividend yield gives a total expected return of 14.7%. Hence, I’m upgrading Civista Bancshares to a buy rating from my previous rating of hold.

The company’s earnings per share are set to decline, and my valuation analysis shows that the market has overreacted to the EPS outlook. It seems the market has discounted Civista Bancshares too much in light of the expected EPS decline. I believe Civista Bancshares should trade higher, and a buy rating is appropriate for the stock.

data.title: Great Elm Capital's Yield Swells To 19.6% On First Brands Group Exposure
data.description:
Great Elm Capital's (GECC) history of dividend cuts could be compounded by a net investment income ("NII") set to dip as the BDC faces intense near-term headwinds from the collapse of First Brands Group ("FBG") and pending Fed rate cuts. FBG was an automotive parts company based in Rochester, Michigan, whose September 29 Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing revealed a web of traditional on-balance sheet debt and invoice-based financing that has ensnared a broad range of large financial institutions, from UBS Group (UBS) and Jefferies (JEF) to smaller boutiques like Raistone, which reportedly had to lay off dozens of its employees as it derived a majority of its income from FBG. GECC is an FBG creditor, publishing a press release on October 07 detailing its total exposure to FBG. The BDC's total exposure is tranched across first lien and second lien loans and stood at $23.3 million at fair market value. The BDC's total debt investment portfolio at fair market value stands at $217.4 million, with the aggregate of the FBG loans forming 10.7% of this. Further, GECC also has more FBG exposure in the CLO component of its total investment portfolio. This was roughly 0.9% across all the CLOs held by the BDC as of the end of its fiscal 2025 second quarter. The BDC is yet to announce a date for its third-quarter earnings.

Critically, the FBG exposure is not insignificant at a double-digit percentage allocation on its core debt investment portfolio. The BDC last declared a quarterly cash dividend of $0.37 per share, kept unchanged from its prior distribution, and $1.48 per share annualized for a 19.6% dividend yield. This yield has moved up to its highest ever level on the back of common shares that have lost around 31% of their value since the start of the year. Bulls would be right to highlight that the common shares have dipped by around 33% since the news of the FBG bankruptcy, a rate that's more than 3x greater than the expected dip to net asset value ("NAV") that's expected from a total loss of the debt investment in FBG. The BDC's allocation to first lien debt is smaller than the broader BDC space at 47% as of the end of the second quarter, with CLOs the second largest allocation at 17% and a growing business for GECC.

Net Asset Value Discount, NII, And Dividend Coverage

GECC reported a second-quarter total investment income of $14.3 million, a new quarterly record and up substantially by 50% from $9.5 million in its year-ago comp. The huge jump in NII came as interest income at $7.97 million was only up 2.7% from its year-ago comp. This was roughly 56% of GECC's total investment income, with dividend income from its equity position jumping to form the remaining 44% of total investment income on the back of a 297% year-over-year jump to $6.24 million from $1.57 million. The second quarter was the highest ever total investment income in GECC's history, driving net investment income up to $5.9 million, around $0.51 per share. This grew by 11 cents sequentially from the first quarter and was up from NII of $0.32 per share a year ago.

The BDC reported second-quarter NAV of $12.10 per share, up by 64 cents per share over the first quarter. The gains were driven by NII and unrealized gains on its investment portfolio. Critically, while the surge in NII meant the company covered its base cash dividend by 138%, shareholders will need to dampen NII expectations for the whole year. GECC described the dividend income as being driven by a once-a-year dividend payment on preferred shares of an insurance-related investment. Further, the BDC stated it expects its third-quarter NII to dip similarly to the retrenchment seen in its fiscal 2024 fourth quarter, when NII came in at $0.20 per share. The quarterly volatility of NII has formed a pillar on which the market has based the current 36% discount to NAV per share the BDC trades on.

The BDC's dividend distribution history is volatile, with the base dividend cut in early 2022, when GECC was paying out a quarterly dividend of $0.45 per share. It would then be raised again to its current level at the start of 2025. The BDC placed two debt investments in Maverick Gaming on non-accrual status during the second quarter. It would add to its non-accruals balance post-period end with the July bankruptcy of Del Monte. The aggregate fair market value of these non-accruals is roughly 3% of GECC's investment portfolio.

The BDC has three outstanding baby bonds: 5.875% Notes due 6/302026 (GECCO), 8.50% Notes Due 2028 (GECCI), and 8.125% Notes Due 12/31/2029 (GECCH). GECCZ was called at the end of September. In terms of liquidity, GECC had $4.4 million in cash and money market funds as of the end of its second quarter. This balance reflects quarterly changes in originations and payoffs, with GECC seeing positive cash from operations in its most recent quarter, and with an average daily trading volume of around 70,000.

Conclusion

GECC sold roughly 1.3 million new shares during the second quarter in a private placement for net proceeds of $14 million. This was followed up with its at-the-market program, allowed the BDC to sell an additional 1.1 million shares for $13 million. This type of dilution, when its common shares are swapping hands at such a steep discount to NAV, heightens the dip of the common shares. The BDC's shares outstanding is up at least 52% over the last 3 years, a pace of dilution that's annualized at 17%. This would form a core reason to not buy the stock, with the ticker being rated as a hold.
